titleStmt.title: A proclimation, by the which is prohibited in the research of the passengers ships betweene France and England, not to vse any disorder in words nor deedes, neither to vse any bad or slaunderous speeches of the Kings Maiestie of Great Britaine, &c. nor his subiects in any manner whatsoeuer translated out of Dutch.

notesStmt.note: Translation of: Placcaet daer by verboden wort int recherceren vande passagiers schepen ..., 1605.--Cf. Petit 814.
"Thus done and concluded by the sayd lords, the Generall Estates being assembled in S'Grauenhaghen, the nineteenth of July anno. 1605."--P. [3]
Reproduction of original in the Harvard University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A PROCLIMATION, BY THE WHICH IS prohibited in the re≈øearch of the Pa≈ø≈øengers Ships betweene France and England, not to v≈øe any di≈øorder in words nor deedes, neither to v≈øe any bad or ≈ølaunderous ≈øpeeches of the Kings Maie≈øtie of Great Britaine, &c. nor his Subiects in any manner what≈øoeuer.
AT LONDON Printed by Thomas Purfoot, for William Fearbrand.

THe generall E≈øtates of the vnited Low-countreys. To all tho≈øe that ≈øhall ≈øee the≈øe pre≈øents or heare them to be read, ≈øend greeting and let to wete, or make knowne. Whereas we are informed, that in the re≈øearch of Pa≈ø≈øengers ≈øhips between France & England by the Ships of Warre, which are in ≈øeruice of the≈øe Countreys, to the end to know whether in the ≈øame there be any Souldiors going towardes the Enemie, or other per≈øons actually of the ≈øeruice of the Enemie, many abu≈øes & wrongs are offered by the Ships Companie, and others which do abord the ≈øaid Pa≈ø≈øengers Ships, as beating, thru≈øting, wronging, and ryfling of the Pa≈ø≈øengers contrarie to our order, good intention, in≈øtruction and all rea≈øon. Likewi≈øe that the Ships Company through ignorance, and otherwi≈øe in the meane time vpon the Ships, but e≈øpectally in the ≈øayd re≈øearch, doe ≈øpeake hardly of the Kings Maie≈øtie of Great Britaine &c. From whom the vnited Prouinces, and the Inhabitants of the ≈øame, many yeeres haue enioyed, and as yet doe enioy many Royall fauors and plea≈øures; vnder pretence that his Maie≈øtie hath made Peace with the King of Spaine: notwith≈øtanding his Maie≈øtie by rea≈øon thereof, hath not changed, altered, nor dimini≈øhed his affections towards the≈øe Countteys in the lea≈øt point, wherein they doe not onely wronge his Maie≈øtie, but al≈øo vs the Inhabitants of the vnited Prouinces in generall. Fora≈ømuch as euerie one is holden and bound to endeuour to requite his Maie≈øties good affection & great fauors with due thanks, and the ≈øame to win and
con≈øerue for the≈øe Countreys, and that ≈øuch mi≈ørules and vnlawful re≈øearch, as al≈øo the ≈øaid bad ≈øpeeches and abu≈øes might happen to breede a di≈øcontentment between his Maie≈øtie and his Subiects with the Inhabitants of the vnited Prouinces, to the preiudice of the welfare of the≈øe Countreys, wherein it is needfull by times by all meanes to fore≈øee. Therefore haue we expre≈øly forbidden and prohibited, doe forbid and prohibite by the≈øe pre≈øents all and ≈øingul ‚Ä¢ e of what condition or qualitie they be, and namely the Commanders ≈øhippe, Captaines, ≈øhippe Officers, and Mariners of the ≈øhips of war of our Fleete, which doe lye in waight in the narrow Seas and vpon the coa≈øts of Flaunders, and all others which ≈øhall be commaunded for the re≈øearch of the ≈øayd Pa≈ø≈øengers ≈øhips between England and Fraunce, not to v≈øe any di≈øorder or vnlawfull meanes by words or deeds, but to doe the ≈øame with all di≈øcretion without beating, thru≈øting, wronging, or ryfling any one. And further we doe forbid all the Inhabitants of the vnited Prouinces and others frequenting the ≈øame: as al≈øo al tho≈øe as are in our ≈øeruice by water or by land, not to v≈øe any bad or iniurious ≈øpeeches of the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie of Great Britaine, &c. nor of his ≈øubiects in any manner of wi≈øe, nor to ≈ølaunder nor impute them with any calumnious ≈øpeeches, vnder any pretence what≈øoeuer, vpon paine to be puni≈øhed, (as di≈øturbers of the Common welfare) in bodie and goods, without contradiction or delay. Prouided alwayes, that we doe not herewith exempt tho≈øe of what Nation or condition ≈øoeuer they be, which ≈øhalbe found by the ≈øayd re≈øearch in ye Pa≈ø≈øengers
Ships going to the ≈øeruice of the King of Spaine, or of the Arch-Dukes, nor tho≈øe which ≈øhalbe found to be in their ≈øeruice, but our expre≈ø≈øe intention and commi≈ø≈øion is, that ≈øuch ≈øhalbe dealt withall and v≈øed according to the order to that effect giuen in the Fleete. And to the end no man doe pretend to be ignorant of the≈øe pre≈øents, we doe ordaine and giue commi≈ø≈øion to our welbeloued the E≈øtates, Gouernors, and committed coun≈øell of the ≈øeuerall Prouinces of Gelderland, and Countie of Sutfen, Holland and We≈øtfree≈øland, Sealand and Wretcht, Free≈øland, Oueri≈ø≈øell, the Towne of Greenighen, and places adioyning, and all others Iu≈øtices, Officers, and Mini≈øters being thereunto required, to make knowne, proclayme and publi≈øh this our order in all places, where it is v≈øuall to publi≈øh & proclayme, charging al≈øo the Gouernors, Pre≈øidents, and provinciall Coun≈øell: likewi≈øe the Colledges of the Admiraltie, the Fi≈øcalladuocats, and al≈øo the generall Atturneys, and all other Officers, Iudges, and Iu≈øtices of the ≈øayd Countreys, and likewi≈øe the Admiral, Vice-Admirals, Chiefetaines, Collonels, Commaunders, Captaines, and Officers to accompli≈øh, and cau≈øe to be accompli≈øhed this our order, and to proceed, & cau≈øe to be proceeded again≈øt the≈øe which ≈øhall doe any thing to the contrarie, without any fauour, grace, di≈ø≈øembling, or forbearance, for ≈øuch is our expre≈ø≈øe meaning.

closer.dateline: Thus done and concluded by the ≈øayd Lords‚ñ™ the generall E≈øtates being a≈ø≈øembled in S'Grauenhaghen, the Nineteenth of Iuly Anno. 1605.
closer.signed: Vnder is written by order of the ≈øayd Lords the generall E≈øtates ≈øub≈øcribed. G. Aer≈ø≈øen.
